definition[0]: a small bag in which women keep paper money, coins, cards etc
example[0]: Julie opened her handbag and took out her purse.
definition[1]: a small bag used to hold coins, used especially by women
definition[2]: a bag in which a woman carries her money and personal things
example[1]: I locked the door and dropped the keys in my purse.
definition[3]: the amount of money that a person, organization, or country has available to spend
example[2]: Election expenses are met from the public purse  (=money controlled by the government).
example[3]: A visit to the new county museum will set the family purse back by around Â£12.
definition[4]: the amount of money given to someone who wins a sports event, such as a boxing match or a car race
example[4]: They will compete for a $100,000 purse.
definition[5]: if you purse your lips, you bring them together tightly into a small circle, especially to show disapproval or doubt
example[5]: Mrs Biddell pursed her lips and shook her head.
example[6]: We offer holidays to suit every purse.
definition[6]: the money controlled by a government
example[7]: The project is a continuing drain on the public purse.
example[8]: These payments should be met out of the public purse.
definition[7]: to control how money in a company, family etc is spent
definition[8]: to increase or reduce the control you have over spending
example[9]: The government has decided that it must now tighten the purse strings.
